p: The World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) no longer classifies WA-MCF as a trans boundary or notifiable disease, however it is of importance in Kenya in regions where cattle co-graze with wildebeest. WA-MCF is viewed as a significant cattle illness in sub Saharan Africa with the highest impact on the livelihoods of cattle-keeping communities [ 24]. The disease has direct impacts on both commercial and smallholder farmers whose economic livelihoods are affected by the death of their cattle and additionally the loss of income from milk and beef sales [ 24, 25].
